3D graphics card which supports OpenGL 3: 3D graphics card which supports OpenGL 3.0 and GLSL 1.3
3D graphics card which supports OpenGL 3.3 and above
A shooting star flashes past the Jupiter: A shooting star flashes past Jupiter. You can select different intensities in the View window.
After building Stellarium itself from th: After building Stellarium itself from the Git code, do 'make apidoc' (you need Doxygen installed). This will create a directory: .../stellarium/builds/doc/html which contains the API documentation in HTML format or you follow this link Doxygen-API
After you have downloaded the .zip file: After you have downloaded the .zip file for a landscape from this page, you need to install it in Stellarium.
As of version 0.10.1, Stellarium uses th: As of version 0.10.1, Stellarium uses the QtScript engine. The previously used StratoScript is no longer available. Even at version 0.16, Stellarium's scripting capabilities and the API change as development continues. Qt5.8 has declared the QtScript module deprecated, so the API may change again a bit. It will remain available in later Qt5 versions, though.
Be aware that many people's video hardwa: Be aware that many people's video hardware cannot handle very large textures. This is hardware and driver dependent. A typical maximum image size is 2048x2048 or 4096x4096.
Before you distribute images as part of: Before you distribute images as part of a Stellarium landscape, please ensure you are legally entitled to - you must be the copyright holder for the images, or be able to distribute them for use with Stellarium under the terms of some agreement with the copyright holder (e.g. Creative Commons licensed images found on the web).
Browse to your User Data Directory, whic: Browse to your User Data Directory, which varies according to your operating system.
Click on the picture to the left for det: Click on the picture to the left for details.
Create a sub-directory called <em>landsc: Create a sub-directory called landscapes in your user directory (if it doesn't exist).
Full sky view of the constellations, the: Full sky view of the constellations, their boundaries and the Milky Way.
Github for hosting the project trackers.
Here you can find API documentation for: Here you can find API documentation for various series of Stellarium. head refers to the latest version from development (although this may lag behind a little as the documentation is only uploaded every so often).
IMPORTANT: Make sure all textures have d: IMPORTANT: Make sure all textures have dimensions which are integer powers of 2, i.e. 256, 512, 1024, 2048, 4096, 8192, 16384, ... e.g. 4096 by 1024, 2048 by 2048 and so on.
If you are using an earlier version of S: If you are using an earlier version of Stellarium, you can follow this procedure to install a landscape package:
If you have Stellarium 0.10.6 or later v: If you have Stellarium 0.10.6 or later version, you can use the 'Add/remove landscapes' feature to install landscapes automatically:
If you have a landscape you would like t: If you have a landscape you would like to share but have no web-space to put it, email to any Stellarium developers and we'll put it on our site.
It is important to explicitly state what: It is important to explicitly state what use may be made of images for your landscape. This should be done in the readme.txt file inside the .zip file.
Landscape packages created without this: Landscape packages created without this feature in mind may contain other files, such as alternative textures in different sizes.
Launchpad for hosting the project tracke: Launchpad for hosting the project trackers.
Linux/Unix; Windows 7 and above; Mac OS: Linux/Unix; Windows 7 and above; Mac OS X 10.12.0 and above
Note that while this makes installing la: Note that while this makes installing landscapes easier, it may also cause you to overlook what else is included in the ZIP archive.
Open the 'Sky and viewing options' windo: Open the 'Sky and viewing options' window by clicking on the appropriate button in the left button bar (or press the F4 key).
Please feel free to contribute your own: Please feel free to contribute your own custom landscapes here. Make thumbnails 200x114 pixels to fit with the rest of the page. Please include a location section in your landscape.ini file with the longitude, latitude, altitude and planet for the location of the landscape (see one of the pre-existing landscapes for an example).
Please make sure all contributed landsca: Please make sure all contributed landscapes conform to these requirements, or your link may be removed.
Please package your landscape in a .zip: Please package your landscape in a .zip file with all files inside a directory in the .zip file. This should be unique to your landscape, and it would be nice if it was all lower-case with no spaces.
Real time chat about Stellarium can be h: Real time chat about Stellarium can be had in the #stellarium IRC channel on the freenode IRC network. Use your favourite IRC client to connect to chat.freenode.net or try the web-based interface.
Search for a planet, nebula, constellati: Search for a planet, nebula, constellation or a specific star. Press enter, and Stellarium centers on the object.
See how different amounts of light pollu: See how different amounts of light pollution make the universe invisible.
Selecting a planet and pressing Ctrl+G f: Selecting a planet and pressing Ctrl+G flies you there.  Here, we see Mars from a rover's viewpoint.
Several people have made significant con: Several people have made significant contributions but are no longer active. Their work has made a big difference to the project
Since version 0.10 Stellarium has new gr: Since version 0.10, Stellarium has a new graphical user interface. The vertical bar links to windows, the horizontal bar shows toggle buttons, just like it used to.
Sourceforge, which has pushed many terab: Sourceforge, which has pushed many terabytes of data for Stellarium during the life of the project.
Special thanks go out to all members of: Special thanks go out to all members of the Stellarium user community.
Stellarium is a free open source planeta: Stellarium is a free open source planetarium for your computer. It shows a realistic sky in 3D, just like what you see with the naked eye, binoculars or a telescope.
Stellarium is produced by the efforts of: Stellarium is produced by the efforts of the developer team, with the help and support of the following people and organisations
Stellarium is produced by the efforts of the developer team, with the help and support of the following people and organisations:
The 'Add/remove landscapes' button is at: The 'Add/remove landscapes' button is at the bottom of the 'Landscape' tab.
The Starlore tab in the View window. Ch: The Starlore tab in the View window.  Choose between different cultures and see how they looked at the stars.
The dance of the planets above ESO headq: The dance of the planets above ESO headquarters, near Munich.
The great nebula in Orion. Press N to br: The great nebula in Orion. Press N to bring up the nebula labels.
The great nebula in Orion. Press N to bring up the nebula labels. Also shown are constellation lines, press C to show or hide them.
The landscape.ini and readme.txt files s: The landscape.ini and readme.txt files should be UTF-8 encoded text or plain ASCII. It's probably a good idea to adopt the Windows line ending encoding, (i.e. CR LF). Both Windows and *nix style line ending encoding should work OK in Stellarium, but Windows users will have an ugly time reading the readme.txt if it uses *nix-style newlines.
The latest development snapshot of Stell: The latest development snapshot of Stellarium is kept on github. If you want to compile development versions of Stellarium, this is the place to get the source code.
The location window. The first thing yo: The location window.  The first thing you have to do is set your observing position and save it. The landscape is a panorama from the ESO facilities in Garching, near Munich, Germany. ESO is the European Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere.
The sun is down, the stars are visible.  Since version 0.10.0, Stellarium has extensive star catalogues.  600,000 stars are included by default, but you can download extra catalogues to see up to 210 million stars. This work was done by our team member Johannes.
This is a limitation of OpenGL. Some vid: This is a limitation of OpenGL. Some video hardware will work OK with images with different image dimensions, but many will not display properly, suffer vastly reduced frame rates, and even crash the computer.
To find out more about how to create a l: To find out more about how to create a landscape, see the Stellarium User Guide, and examine existing landscapes. If you are having problems, posting to the forums is a good way to get some advice.
To install a script copy the script file: To install a script copy the script file (.ssc extension), and any texture files it uses to the scripts sub-directory of your User Data Directory. Instructions with many of these community-donated scripts may date back to older versions of Stellarium, and the instructions provided with the script may be out of date.
Transifex for hosting the project transl: Transifex for hosting the project translation system.
Unzip the landscape .zip file in the <em: Unzip the landscape .zip file in the landscapes directory (if it's done right, a sub-directory should be created for each landscape).
We have landscapes for the seven contine: We have landscapes for the seven continents (in the seven continent model) - all, including from Antarctica!
We recommend an open source license comp: We recommend an open source licence compatible with Stellarium itself (i.e. the GNU GPL), or one of the Creative Commons licences.
When you press it, the 'Add/remove lands: When you press it, the 'Add/remove landscapes' window will appear. It allows you to install .zip files containing landscapes. It also lists the user-installed landscapes and allows you to remove them.
You can learn more about Stellarium, get: You can learn more about Stellarium, get support and help the project via these links
You should also include a readme.txt fil: You should also include a readme.txt file which describes the landscape and specifies any usage restrictions or licensing terms for the images used in the landscape.
